page.title: 02HISTORICAL BACKGROUND
page.content: THERE ARE VARIOUS SUGGESTIONS AS TO HOW HARROW GOT ITS NAME BUT THE MOST GENERALLY ACCEPTED ONE IS THAT IT COMES FROM THE ANGLO-SAXON WORD{HEARH MEANING A HILL SANCTUARY.IN THE ORIGINAL{DOMESDAY}OF 1086 HARROW IS RECORDED AS BELONGING TO LANFRANC, ARCHBISHOP OF CANTERBURY AND AS HAVING A PRIEST,3 KNIGHTS AND THEIR 7 TENANTS, 102 VILLEINS (PEASANTS) 2 COTTAGERS AND 2 SERFS. ITS LANDS AMOUNTED TO NEARLY 13,000 ACRES. HARROW REMAINED AS A VILLAGE UNTIL AFTER THE FIRST WORLD WAR WHEN SUDDEN EXPANSION INTO THE SUBURBS TOOK PLACE. THE METROPOLITAN RAILWAY CO.HAD A MAJOR EFFECT ON HARROW'S GROWTH WITH ITS{METROLAND}ADVERTISING CAMPAIGN EXTOLLING THE VIRTUES OF SUBURBAN LIVING WITH EASY ACCESS TO LONDON.
